information_for_contributors: This file has been converted from https://github.com/PowerShell/EditorSyntax/blob/master/PowerShellSyntax.tmLanguage
If you want to provide a fix or improvement, please create a pull request against the original repository.
Once accepted there, we are happy to receive an update request.
name: PowerShell

patterns.comment: type without accessor or attribute needed in statement mode, mostly for [flags()] before an `enum`.
if type advanced, test for attribute qualified keywords
if not a type or attribute, try finishing in command mode
`;` resume's in statement mode.
$self may have been combined with other includes, this will insure its just $self now
default assignment for a property
optional user specified type, PowerShell Core >= 6.2.0
begin at the first token in the expression, to test for numeric and unary operators
allow for possibility that numeric value or unary operators match first, before resuming in expression mode
if neither numeric or a pre-unary operator, just finish in expression mode
normally provided by command mode, but thats not available here
patterns.name: constant.character.escape.powershell

patterns.comment: `,`, `&` and `|` not permitted here
patterns.name: invalid.source.powershell

patterns.comment: function names that start with `:` are treated differently

do,for,foreach,switch,while: allow a `:label` that must start the statement; A `:label` before a loop looks just like a function, and its possible to put the loop keyword on a later line!  Here we just see if a valid label appears to be the only useful thing on a single line
break,continue: permit a label following, then revert back to statement mode
`;` not permitted here
patterns.name: invalid.terminator.statement.powershell

patterns.comment: next statement, return when safe to exit
only allow foreach arguments before the `(`

`,`, `<` and `>` not permitted here

next statement, return when safe to exit

from,var,define are reserved; configuration is TODO, needs significant syntax structure work.

patterns.comment: (dot) source operator, requires trailing space, or invoke operator
Next token needs to be an operand for the operator, not the actual command, but an expression or unquoted expandable string that describes the command's name.
at the begining of a command name, `<`, `>` or `>>` are the entire command name.
patterns.name: entity.name.function.powershell

patterns.comment: Next token needs to be an operand for the operator, not the actual command, but an expression or unquoted expandable string that describes the command's name.
could be a numeric constant or a limited list of unary operators, that we should switch to expression mode
if unary operators/numeric constant advanced, switch to expression mode
if neither numeric or a pre-unary operator, try finishing command mode with a command name

patterns that indicate an expression, might be able to simplify this to include expression_mode and then see if the cursor advanced, sorta, don't forget about 'notCode', maybe check operand/operator only first, as redirect could also be a problem.
catch that which didn't match elsewhere
patterns.name: invalid.source.powershell

patterns.comment: command names are allowed to start with < or >, without a backtick, but `function` requires a backtick.  See below!
at the begining of a command name, `]`, `<`, `>` or `>>` are the entire command name.
patterns.name: entity.name.function.powershell

patterns.comment: function names that start with `:` are treated differently
could be variable reference, if it doesn't have member reference, its the start of an unquoted expandable string
check out the first variable reference
if a member access doesn't occur after variable, finish as an unquoted expandable string argument.
attempt another argument after member access
splatting cannot have members and certain characters following, including no line comment
splatting cannot have members and certain characters following, including no line comment
patterns.name: invalid.splat.powershell

patterns.comment: `,` just continues current mode, after advancing to next token

expression_mode.comment: Keep in mind, before begining expression mode, check for prefixed unary operators, but check for numeric constants before that!  This is done for each area that forwards to expression mode.

patterns.ig_comment: patterns that indicate an operand, might be able to simplify this to include expression_mode and then see if the cursor advanced, sorta, don't forget about 'notCode', maybe check operand/operator only first, as redirect could also be a problem.

patterns.comment: normally operands win matches first, but numeric constant and operators share common first characters, and their matching needs to be alternated such that after any operand matches, a check for operators should occur before a numeric value is checked for again.  Operators needs to have first priority of a match after a numeric constant.

Once an operator has matched, subsequently #operators_preunary should be checked first until the next non operator token is found.  However, an operator might have matched before we've even gotten here (pre-unary)
preunary operators are technically part of an operand expression
very limited what is permitted here

patterns.comment: capture a complete variable reference that appears on a single line and attempt to scope language variables
this captures up to the first colon, and then matches up the capture
splatting cannot be used outside of argument mode, result is invalid source.
patterns.name: invalid.splat.powershell

RequiresDirective.comment: requires directive must be on single line, so capture and tokenize, current PS <= 6.2 allow `requires` keyword without delimiter, but the parameters must follow with a delimiter!

patterns.comment: needs custom argument handler, single line quoted or unquoted arguments
patterns.name: variable.parameter.powershell

patterns.comment: needs custom hashtable that does not auto continue to next line

RequiresDirective.name: comment.line.powershell meta.requires.powershell

#variable
#quotedStrings_Members

quotedStrings_Members.comment: detect all quoted strings (arguments or expressions) starting here

patterns.comment: double quoted here-strings
single quoted here-strings
backtick at end of function name cannot continue line, becomes literal
backtick at end of unquoted text cannot continue line, becomes literal
`||` and `&&` conditional terminators are reserved.
patterns.name: invalid.reserved.powershell

operators_post.comment: expression mode operators that follow operands mutually exclusive of each other.

patterns.comment: the range operator is only available after an operand (but is a binary operator)

operators_preUnary.comment: expression mode unary operators that precede operands.

patterns.comment: `,` just continues current mode, after advancing to next token
`,` just continues current mode, after advancing to next token
selector (ternary) operator
this will inadvertantly detect successive `:` without an operand between them
included last only because preunary also includes the negate `!` and `-b?not` operators, but we didn't want the `-` negate operator replacing `-` subtract.
when nothing else matches in usual tokenizing, consume it to prevent other patterns from striking in the middle of what might be a command name.
`&` resume's in statement mode, added PowerShell 6 (previously reserved)
`|` resume's in command mode
`,`, `<` and `>` not permitted here
patterns.name: invalid.source.powershell
